we oversold the event which is fantastic news we underestimated the amount of
demand for this all these projects and I think we're very much on the ascending
side of the hype curve but as I'll talk about where we're going to keep growing
and make room for more folks so I'm going to give you a hopefully a pretty
brief cloud native State of the Union where we came from and my own personal
interpretation of a history of the cloud why we're here and excited about cloud native technology what we can do better
and there are multiple things the little padding on the back of things we're doing well and then a little hint
forward on where we're going but before I start I would like to very much thank
our sponsors our diamond sponsors aprender Cisco core OS Google cloud
platform huawei IBM Intel and Red Hat our platinum sponsors Tiger of VMware we
have we've works and you can see we have a number of great companies for gold sponsors and the silver folks I urge you
to please go out and chat with these people they all have interesting stories they I do think that's the hallway track
and some of the booth interactions can be parts of the most valuable pieces of
these conferences and of course we couldn't be here without these folks so thank you all very much okay so a brief
history of the cloud let's go back in time to 2000 I was a venture capitalist
in Palo Alto and companies would come to me and say yeah we have this little idea
this little thing we need to do we need two million dollars just to buy the hardware to get going based on our hope
of what the demand would be will be and so the building block of an
application was a physical server and when you needed to expand or deploy a
new application you would call up your son salesperson and say I need a new server or maybe a new rack of them which
is why son was doing so well for a while there and then we bring our time machine
forward 2001 you had VMware popularized the concept of virtual machines so now
you can put your application into a VM it thinks it's heads it has its own server but in fact you can multiplex
multiple VMs on the same physical server and that really completely changed the
way people think about deploying applications that the building block of an application as you're thinking about
it becomes a VM not a physical machine fast forward to 2006 when Amazon Web
Services launched ec2 really popularized the concept of Iyaz and this was just a
massive change that you no longer needed to pre-buy all your servers they stopped
being capex that you had to raise tons of money for they became an operating expense you could expand and contract by
the hour and but interestingly the architectural building block was still the same thing it was a VM it was just
renamed to be an ami an Amazon machine image and now we jump to 2009 and you
had this startup Heroku which I think for many of us really changed the way we thought about application development
popularized that the whole concept of DevOps and the idea was that if you follow these rules what they called a 12
factor application about how you dealt with the stateful data and the deployment mechanism and a few other
things that you had this magic experience as you made an improvement or
fixed a bug or rolled out a new feature you can type git push Heroku and a few seconds later you would see that new
version live on the website and it really was just and still is an incredible experience now it turns out
that Heroku uses containers but that process is totally opaque to the consumer and they don't even really
think of things called build packs okay so those are the halfway through our tour here interestingly that's the end of the
proprietary companies now we jump to open source and so in 2010 you had
OpenStack from NASA and Rackspace and then slew of other companies joined in
and in a lot of ways they were just taking what VMware had done and what AWS
was doing and saying okay can we create an open-source platform for this that any company can roll this out and have
their own AI as offering or individual enterprises can do this and and and have an ec2 like offering but and it I think
it took a little longer than they wanted to there were some hiccups along the way but this ultimately did fulfill its
original vision but it's important to note that the building block remained a
virtual machine now we go to 2011 when a pivotal created the cloud foundry
platform and this has some semblance to it and some extra features and other sorts of things but for a ton of users
especially big enterprises it was really an open source alternative to Heroku and it created that kind of magic of a
continuous deployment pipeline 12 factor app rollout but doing it on lots of
different hardware and not just not just with Heroku and then we fast forward to
2013 when docker came out and what's interesting about docker I think of it
like Tim berners-lee creating the World Wide Web where you look at what was in there and you say boy you know HCP
wasn't actually that different from FTP and HTML was kind of based on XML and URLs aren't actually that innovative and
yet sometimes when you just glue together these existing technologies in the right way and critically create a
really useable user interface around it magic happens and similarly solomon
hikes took LXE and union file systems and c groups these different features that were already in the kernel and he
kind of married them together and with a little secret sauce around usability has
produced what was really been the fastest uptake of a developer technology ever that you don't need to have a
fleet operating system around your application the application can be contained can live next to other apps
and will go through it but you get things like isolation reuse immutability and so this was a critical moment
because the building block of the application was no longer a VM but now
became a container and then we'll fast forward to December 2015 of cloud native
and we defined cloud native as having three key components to it so you take your application and you divide it up
into different pieces what we call Micro Services where each of those can be running its own on its own framework on
some programming language with different dependencies with different versions and it's incredibly helpful as your team
gets bigger that everyone doesn't have to be committing to the same repo then you package each of those micro services
up into its own container and critically you dynamically orchestrate those containers in order to optimize the
resource utilization so the cloud native computing foundation was formed in December 2015 Google donated kubernetes
which of course is behind cube con and why many of us are here but then we've
also had prometheus and other projects and we are now trying to tell story
about where this goes so what have we learned from that process the core
building block went from servers to VMs to build packs that's the Heroku Cloud Foundry to
containers that's from heavier to lighter weight both in spin up time and size the immutability is a key point
that this concept of treating your servers and your containers like cattle and not like pets that no one should
ever be individually configuring anything everything's reproducible and then the provider has gone from closed
source from a single company to open source cross vendor so that all these projects and the stack is available to
download and then you can get commercial support from a vendor if you want it or need it and if you're not happy you can
go to a different vendor or a different cloud and still stick with the same stack
and then I'll just mention paths because I do think there's a still a ton of magic around 12 factor and I kind of
estimate that for most companies 80% of their applications fit great into a past environment but what's interesting about
kubernetes and other cloud native orchestration platforms is that they represent a great base for building a pass on top of and so you see red hat
with OpenShift Huawei has Cee Cee Deus has workflow a prenda has their own
path these are all platforms that are built on top of kubernetes and this is
great because many applications start out as a 12 factor app that's perfect for paths sometimes they outgrow it some
apps never actually fit app as model so pads on top of a cloud native platform
supports all those deployment models okay so that's the at least my
interpretation of history the last 16 years or so why are we excited about
cloud native so the key value propositions isolation and so this is uh
my docker slide because they really did pioneer this so the idea that when you
can containerize your application you get dev prod parity you can have the same version in development and
production you have faster code and component reuse you can simplify operations we get no lock-in and so this
is just the story of open source that there are lots of vendors out in the hallway who are eager to help you and
work with you but when you pick one of them you're not stuck for the next decade if they're not meeting your needs
scalability so this actually this statistic from Google is two years old now but that at that point they were
starting two billion containers per week which I believe is thirteen hundred a minute and the idea is that you can
scale to tens of thousands of self-healing multi-tenant nodes and actually several of our presentations
today are going to talk about some of the biggest implementations out there the one that my young sons are
particularly impressed by is that Pokemon go you might have seen is running on kubernetes today
yes and agility and maintainability so I'm talking about micro-services here
I'll give a quick shout-out to these incredibly productive pirates who really had to work hard to get those containers
into the different boats but the idea is that you put each of the applications in
a container you define how they depend on each other these explicitly describe dependencies
and each of the containers can scale separately and then our orchestration
picture so improved efficiency and resource utilization that you dynamically manage and schedule the
microservices you don't have to just set it up and hope that it's correct you can explain to the cluster what the demands
are and have it adjust dynamically based on demand and other requirements and that also brings us to resiliency so
that your individual containers can fail your machine can fail even entire data centers you can respond to varying
levels of demand and your application keeps running the way you expect it to so that's the goal of cloud native
